item.title: You are a person, not a product
item.description: In this post I’m explaining why I’m going to close down my Twitter account in favor of the Mastodon social network. Why exactly is Twitter (or Facebook etc.) providing services to us? It’s their business. They want to make money off of us. Users are their asset. They do not strive to make it a good place for you and me, but a good place for their business interests, a good place to let us see ads for example.

item.title: The best terminal font
item.description: I have long tried to find the best-looking font to be used with the terminal or my favorite editor Emacs, but none of all the options look as good to me as the traditional misc fixed font from the X.org server.

item.title: Syncthing for the win
item.description: For a long time I had my own server running Nextcloud to sync my files to other computers and mobile devices. It was working quite well. But what if you don’t have your own server? What if you don’t want to use a server?

item.title: Email is not a todo list
item.description: Let’s see if I can make your life a bit easier today. I want to address email and how you deal with your email. And how it is more of a nuisance for you than it should be.

item.title: Gnome Desktop UX Review
item.description: I have been working with Debian GNU/Linux (yes, GNU to acknowledge what Richard Stallman has done and is still doing to free us from proprietary software) as my desktop (or laptop) OS for many years now and I’m very happy with it.

item.title: Edititing files with Emacs via ssh and sudo
item.description: Emacs has pretty impressive remote file editing capabilites through tramp.el (Transparent Remote Access, Multiple Protocol) – especially via ssh. It is even possible to use git on a remote server through Emacs.

item.title: Shell commands with GNU sed
item.description: sed is useful to replace some text on the fly. But how about processing text on the fly with shell commands instead of just replacing it with fixed content?

item.title: ssh Agent Forwarding
item.description:
Quite often it is necessary to ssh via an intermediate host if the destination host is not directly accessible through ssh. Usually people do this:

ssh user@host1
ssh host2
# you'll have to enter your password

item.title: Google Fu
item.description:
In years of googling have learned a few things. Most importantly:

Most people don’t know how to google efficiently

And this makes all the difference today, whether you are trying to learn, fix a problem, find a new job, flat or car. Good googling helps you in your job, it helps you with your hobby, your research, your studies - in short: everywhere.

item.title: Download and unzip in one command
item.description:
With tar it is possible to do something like this:

wget -O- http://example.com/my.tar.gz | tar xvz
